supporting.text: Cats are obligate carnivores and their bodies are adapted to obtain most of their hydration from prey, making water their primary and safest source of hydration.

attacks.text: Cats are obligate carnivores and their bodies are adapted to obtain most of their hydration from prey, making water their primary and safest source of hydration.
Some cats may prefer or require alternative hydration sources, such as broth or wet food, especially if they are reluctant to drink plain water.
Wild cats often consume blood and other fluids from prey, which can supplement their hydration needs beyond just water.
While alternative hydration sources exist, water remains the most universally safe and accessible option for all cats, regardless of individual preferences.
Domestic cats do not have the same access to prey as wild cats, making water a more reliable and necessary source of hydration.

supporting.text: Other liquids like milk can cause digestive issues such as diarrhea in many cats due to lactose intolerance.

attacks.text: Other liquids like milk can cause digestive issues such as diarrhea in many cats due to lactose intolerance.

Even if some cats tolerate milk, it does not provide any essential nutrients that water does not already offer.

supporting.text: Water is essential for kidney function, and cats are prone to kidney diseases, making it critical to avoid unnecessary additives or substitutes.

attacks.text: Water is essential for kidney function, and cats are prone to kidney diseases, making it critical to avoid unnecessary additives or substitutes.

supporting.text: Flavored or sweetened beverages can lead to obesity or diabetes in cats, while water has no such risks.

attacks.text: Flavored or sweetened beverages can lead to obesity or diabetes in cats, while water has no such risks.

supporting.text: Some specially formulated cat milk substitutes are safe in moderation and can provide additional nutrients, contradicting the claim that cats should only drink water.

supporting.text: In rare cases, veterinarians may recommend electrolyte solutions for dehydrated cats, which are not plain water.

attacks.text: In rare cases, veterinarians may recommend electrolyte solutions for dehydrated cats, which are not plain water.
